DOC.HEAD: Manville to Speed Up Payment to Asbestos Victims' Trust
DOC.TEXT: Manville Corp. says it will accelerate payment of a $50 million note to the asbestos victims' trust fund created by its bankruptcy reorganization, according to the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday, the Trust said it had been exploring ways to improve liquidity after a plan for Manville to repurchase $500 million of its preferred stock fell through earlier this month. ``One of those alternatives is an offer by Manville to accelerate the payment of its $50 million Trust note,'' the SEC filing said. The note was to be repaid in two equal payments on Sept. 15 1990 and the same date a year later. ``The Trust and Manville have agreed in principle that Manville will pay the $50 million principal amount of the note together with accumulated interest of approximately $8 million to the trust on or about Dec. 28, 1989,'' the three-page filing with the SEC said. Spokespersons for both Denver-based Manville and the Washington, D.C.-based trust confirmed that an agreement in principle had been reached. ``Manville and the trust anticipate that discussions will continue, from time to time, regarding mutually acceptable methods for improving the trust's financial flexibility and enhancing value for all shareholders,'' the SEC filing said. In October, Manville _ a forest products and construction materials concern _ offered to purchase about $500 million of its preferred stock from the trust at market prices. On Dec. 7, however, both the trust and Manville announced that plan had been withdrawn because of a failure to agree on details of the agreement. Both Manville and the Trust said they anticipated future discussions ``regarding mutually acceptable methods for improving the trust's financial flexibility and enhancing value for all shareholders.'' The trust was created as part of Manville's bankruptcy reorganization in the late 1980s after a wave of health claims over asbestos-related diseases forced the company to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law. The trust was created on Nov. 28, 1988, the same day Manville emerged from reorganization proceedings. Since then, the trust has settled more than 15,000 personal injury cases, paying out more than $600 million to injured victims. The trust owns 50 percent, 24 million shares, of Manville's new common stock as well as convertible preferred stock and a $1.8 billion bond. Beginning in 1992, the trust will receive 20 percent of Manville's net profits, under the terms of the agreement that created the trust.
